{{Infobox Military Structure |name = Worcester Castle |location = [[Worcester]], [[Worcestershire]], England |coordinates = {{gbmapping|SO849543}} |image = [[File:Reconstruction of Worcester Castle.jpg|225px]] |caption = Reconstruction of Worcester Castle as it was in 1250 AD{{#tag:ref|Reconstruction by [[Worcester City Art Gallery & Museum|Worcester City Museums.]]|group="nb"}} |map_type = Worcestershire |latitude = 52.1861 |longitude = -2.2214 |coord_display = title |coord_region = GB |map_size = 200 |map_alt = |map_caption = Shown within [[Worcestershire]] |type = [[Motte and bailey]] |materials = |height = |condition = Demolished |ownership = |open_to_public = |battles = |events = }} '''Worcester Castle''' was a [[Norman people|Norman]] fortification built between 1068 and 1069 in [[Worcester]], England by [[Urse d'Abetot]] on behalf of [[William the Conqueror]]. The castle had a [[motte-and-bailey]] design and was located on the south side of the old [[Anglo-Saxon]] city, cutting into the grounds of [[Worcester Cathedral]]. Royal castles were owned by the king and maintained on his behalf by an appointed [[constable]]. At Worcester that role was passed down through the local Beauchamp family on a hereditary basis, giving them permanent control of the castle and considerable power within the city. The castle played an important part in the wars of the 12th and early 13th century, including [[the Anarchy]] and the [[First Barons' War]].
In 1217, [[Henry III of England|Henry III]]'s government decided to break the power of the Beauchamps and reduce the ongoing military threat posed by the castle by returning much of the castle's bailey to the cathedral. Without an intact bailey the castle was no longer valuable militarily, although it played a small part in the [[Second Barons' War]] in the 1260s. A [[gaol]] had been built in the castle by the early 13th century and the castle continued to be used as [[Worcestershire]]'s county gaol until the 19th century, when a new prison was built on the north side of Worcester and the old site completely redeveloped. Today nothing remains of Worcester Castle with the exception of Edgar's Tower, a cathedral gatehouse built on the former entrance to the castle.
==History==
===11th century=== Worcester Castle was built after the [[Norman conquest of England]] in the Anglo-Saxon city of Worcester. The castle was constructed between 1068 and 1069 on the orders of William the Conqueror as part of a wave of royal castle building in major Roman or Anglo-Saxon towns across England.<ref>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', p. 7</ref> Constructed in timber, the castle had a motte-and-bailey design, with a bailey to the north and south of the motte.<ref name=BakerHoltP158>Baker and Holt, ''Urban Growth and the Medieval Church'', p. 158</ref> The top of the motte was later recorded as being around 18 feet (5.5 m) in diameter.<ref name=BritHist/> The castle was defensively well situated on the eastern bank of the [[River Severn]] in the south-west corner of the borough, taking advantage of the old ''[[burh]]'' walls and ditches.<ref name=BritHist>''[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=42914 The city of Worcester: The castle and public buildings]'', A History of the County of Worcester: volume 4 (1924), pp. 390–394, accessed 9 October 2011.</ref> [[Urse d'Abetot]] was appointed as the [[High Sheriff of Worcestershire|sheriff of Worcester]] and the [[constable]] of the new castle.<ref name=MackenzieP386>Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 386</ref>
Worcester was an urban castle, built within an existing settlement.<ref>Creighton, ''Castles and Landscapes'', p.134</ref> Many such castles required the clearance of local properties, but unusually at Worcester Castle the ditch of the outer bailey cut through part of Worcester Cathedral's [[cemetery]]. It is unclear whether the cemetery was still in use at that time, but the desecration resulted in [[Ealdred (bishop)|Ealdred]], the [[Archbishop of York]], with extensive interests in Worcester, complaining about the seizure of the land and formally [[curse|cursing]] Urse.<ref>Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 386; Creighton, ''Castles and Landscapes'', p. 123</ref>
===12th–13th centuries=== [[File:Worcester castle plan.png|thumb|250px|Plan of the castle before 1217. A – Water gate; B – motte; C – ditch; D – bailey; E – Frog Mill; F – gatehouse; G – city wall]] Worcester remained a royal castle, but within a few years the post of sheriff and that of constable became hereditary in the Beauchamp family, the successors to Urse d'Abitot. Urse's son, Roger, inherited them, followed by Walter de Beauchamp, who married Urse's daughter, and William de Beauchamp.<ref>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', pp. 27, 96; Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 386</ref> The castle was effectively run by the Beauchamps, largely independent of the king.<ref name=PoundsP96>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', p. 96</ref> Despite controlling Worcester, the Beauchamps preferred to use [[Elmley Castle (castle)|Elmley Castle]], 12 miles (20 k) away, as their main residence.<ref name=PoundsP210>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', p. 210</ref> In 1113 Worcester was attacked by Welsh raiders, who broke into the outer bailey of the castle and set fire to the buildings there; the timber castle was destroyed and had to be rebuilt, again in wood.<ref>Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 387; Armitage, ''The Early Norman Castles'', p. 241</ref>
In the late 1130s a period of civil war – [[the Anarchy]] – broke out in England, in which the rival factions of [[Stephen of England|King Stephen]] and the [[Empress Matilda]] contested the kingdom; Worcestershire proved to be a key battleground in the war.<ref name=MackenzieP386/> The first attack on Worcester itself occurred in late 1139, when an Angevin army from Gloucestershire assaulted the city; after an attempt to take the castle on the south side of the city, the Gloucester forces entered from the north, looting and burning the city.<ref>Bradbury, ''Stephen and Matilda'', p. 85</ref> As a result, Walter de Beauchamp chose to side with Matilda.<ref name=MackenzieP387>Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 387</ref> Worcester became a base for Stephen's forces for a period, with Stephen replacing Walter as the constable with [[Waleran de Beaumont, 1st Earl of Worcester|Waleron de Beaumont]], before the city and castle were reclaimed for the Empress by [[Robert, 1st Earl of Gloucester|Robert of Gloucester]].<ref>Mackenzie, ''The Castles of England'', p. 387; Bradbury, p. 156</ref> In response, Stephen first stormed and burnt the city in 1148, and then attacked it again in 1150, shortly before the end of the conflict.<ref>Bradbury, pp. 156, 182</ref> Two neighbouring siege castles were built by Stephen as part of these operations, designed to contain Worcester Castle itself,<ref name=MackenzieP387/> one at Henwick Hill the other at Red Hill. After the conflict, Walter was finally reaffirmed as the constable of Worcester Castle by [[Henry II of England|Henry II]], the Empress's son.<ref name=MackenzieP387/>
By the end of the 13th century, William de Beauchamp – the grandson of Walter de Beauchamp – controlled the castle on behalf of the king.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> In the 12th century there was a trend in England for stone castles to replace their earth and timber counterparts, and in 1204 [[John of England|King John]] ordered the sheriff of Worcester to rebuild the [[gatehouse]] "which is now of timber, with good and fine stone".<ref>Allen Brown ''Allen Brown's English Castles'' p. 55</ref> John's work cost £25, and was one of a number of repairs and improvements during the period: £12 was spent maintaining the castle in 1183, for example, while in 1192 £5 4s was spent on the internal buildings and in 1203 work on the stables came to £6 3s.<ref name=BritHist/>{{#tag:ref|It is impossible to accurately compare 12th and 13th century prices with modern equivalents. For comparison, £25 represents around a quarter of the average annual income for an late 12th century baron.<ref>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', p. 147.</ref>|group="nb"}}
[[File:Worcester Castle 1610.jpg|thumb|left|[[John Speed]]'s depiction of the castle motte (l) and bailey (r) in 1610]] [[First Barons' War|Civil war]] broke out again in England in 1215 between forces loyal to [[John of England|King John]] and rebel barons, supported in due course by [[Louis VIII of France|Prince Louis]] of France. John annexed the castle in 1214 and William sided with the rebels in 1216.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> King John responded by sending forces to attack the castle and successfully retook it.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> Despite John's death, the war continued until forces loyal to John's young son, [[Henry III of England|Henry III]], finally achieved victory over the rebels in 1217.
Meanwhile, the 11th century dispute over the cathedral graveyard had continued unabated and in 1217 Henry III's government decided to announce that the disputed land would be granted to the cathedral.<ref name=PoundsP210/> A panel met to agree exactly how the land should be divided, concluding that the division should run straight across the bailey; the far side was returned to the cathedral, making the remainder of the castle unusable from a military perspective.<ref name=PoundsP210/> Henry thus ingratiated himself with the church and broke the power of the Beauchamps in the city by crippling their local fortress.<ref name=PoundsP96/>
The castle nevertheless continued in use for a time, partially because the Worcestershire [[Gaol|County gaol]] was situated in the outer bailey; the earliest record of this gaol is from 1221, when a porter was recorded as being employed as a gaoler.<ref>Pugh, ''Imprisonment in Medieval England'', pp. 85, 146</ref> The gaol appears to have been built of wood during the medieval period.<ref>Pugh, ''Imprisonment in Medieval England'', pp. 350–351</ref> Escapees remained a problem; some were recorded during the 1220s, and during [[Second Barons' War]], Worcester was captured and all the prisoners released.<ref>Pugh, ''Imprisonment in Medieval England'', pp. 219, 224</ref> Later in the same war, Henry III was imprisoned there for a period by [[Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester|Simon de Montfort]].<ref name=MackenzieP387/> The castle was also used as one of the locations for the Worcestershire county court and election of local officials.<ref name=BritHist/>
===14th–19th centuries=== [[File:Worcester Castle 1651.jpg|thumb|Worcester Castle in 1651, with a [[sconce (fortification)|sconce]] built on top of the motte]] The sheriffs of Worcestershire continued to control the castle as constables, and the property passed along hereditary lines from the Beauchamps to the [[Earl of Warwick|Earls of Warwick]] until [[Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick|Richard Neville]], also known as the "Kingmaker", died during the [[Wars of the Roses]] in 1471. The victorious [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]] divided up the various estates that Neville had owned and gave the castle to his son, severing the link between Worcester and the earldom of Warwick.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> The final constables were appointed during the 1540s, after which the practice of appointing constables ceased altogether.<ref name=BritHist/> The castle's walls were quarried for stone, the motte was used to keep animals on and only the sheriff's county gaol remained intact.<ref>Pounds, ''The Medieval Castle in England and Wales'', p.96.</ref> The [[antiquarian]] [[John Leland (antiquary)|John Leland]] recorded in the 1540s that the castle was "now clean down", and that the motte was still of an impressive size but heavily overgrown.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> A gatehouse known as Edgar's Tower was built by the cathedral on the site of the earlier castle gatehouse, to control access to the former bailey.<ref>Armitage, ''The Early Norman Castles'', p.241</ref>
In 1628 the castle site was granted by the Crown to Giles Clutterbuck; the local gentry complained, leading to a legal case in which the county successfully reclaimed the site.<ref name=BritHist/> In 1642 England descended into a period of [[English Civil War|civil war]] between the Royalist supporters of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] and the [[Roundhead|supporters of Parliament]]. Worcester's city walls were refortified and a [[sconce (fortification)|sconce]], or small fort, was built on top of the motte of Worcester Castle.<ref>''[http://www.worcester.gov.uk/fileadmin/assets/pdf/Leisure___Culture/archeology/Adopted_CMP_report/WCD_CMP_Gazetteer1.pdf Worcester City Defences: Conservation Management Plan]'', Oxford Archaeology, pp.102, January 2007, accessed 11 October 2011.</ref>
The castle continued to be used as the county gaol after the war and in 1653 a new gaol, built from stone and brick, was constructed in the castle grounds.<ref name=BritHist/> In the 1770s the prison reformer [[John Howard (prison reformer)|John Howard]] inspected the gaol and was very critical of the facility. In particular he complained about the castle's underground dungeon, accessed down a flight of 26 steps; the room was circular, 18 feet (5.5 m) across, and guarded by an iron grill.<ref name=CommitteeP1>Committee of the Society for the Improvement of Prison Discipline, ''Remarks on the form and construction of prisons'' p.1.</ref> Worcester conducted extensive work after the report at a cost of £3,431 (£364,000 at 2009 prices), and by 1788 the prison had 18 new cells for men and two for women, in addition to the dungeon and the sick-rooms. Nevertheless it was housing 74 inmates at the time of Howard's inspection, with two prisoners routinely sharing each cell, sleeping together on the floor.<ref>Howard, ''An Account of the Principal Lazarettos in Europe'', p. 172; ''[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=42914 The city of Worcester: The castle and public buildings]'', A History of the County of Worcester: volume 4 (1924), pp. 390–394, accessed 9 October 2011; ''[http://www.measuringworth.com/ Purchasing Power of British Pounds from 1264 to Present]'', MeasuringWorth, Lawrence H. Officer and Samuel H. Williamson, accessed 12 October 2011</ref> Like other prisons of the time, Worcester Castle was run as a private enterprise, in this case by a local [[butcher]], who was paid £150 a year (£15,400) to run the facility.<ref>Howard, ''An Account of the Principal Lazarettos in Europe'', p. 172; ''[http://www.measuringworth.com/ Purchasing Power of British Pounds from 1264 to Present]'', MeasuringWorth, Lawrence H. Officer and Samuel H. Williamson, accessed 12 October 2011.</ref> The prison was known to suffer from outbreaks of gaol fever, which claimed the life of a local doctor who visited the facility.<ref name=CommitteeP1/>
A new county gaol was built in 1814, at a cost of £20,000 (£1.1m) with a more modern system of radiating wings; this was constructed on the north side of Worcester where the local street was named "Castle Street" as a result.<ref>Committee of the Society for the Improvement of Prison Discipline, ''Remarks on the form and construction of prisons'' p. 22; ''[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=42914 The city of Worcester: The castle and public buildings]'', A History of the County of Worcester: volume 4 (1924), pp. 390–394, accessed 9 October 2011; ''[http://www.measuringworth.com/ Purchasing Power of British Pounds from 1264 to Present]'', MeasuringWorth, Lawrence H. Officer and Samuel H. Williamson, accessed 12 October 2011</ref> The [[Dean (religion)|Dean and Chapter]] of [[Worcester Cathedral]] acquired the old gaol in 1823. The outer bailey of the castle became known as the College Green; the College Green was accessed through Edgar's Tower.<ref name=MackenzieP387/> The motte was slowly demolished between 1823 and 1846.<ref name=MackenzieP387/>
